gov.usgs.anss.utilinv

Class DBObject

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.usgs.anss.utilinv.DBObject

  • public class DBObject
extends java.lang.Object
    This routine basically forms an object wrapping a ResultSet for one record from a JDBC table. When a new one is created, it is read back using the created and created_by fields (unlikely anyone could create more than one record in one table at precisely the right time). It then behaves just like one that was read. The getter and setter methods by data type are use to manipulate the data. This routine requires the following in the creation of the table : CREATE TABLE name? ( ID INT(6) UNSIGNED NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT, PRIMARY KEY (ID), updated TIMESTAMP, created_by INT(6), created TIMESTAMP); The created and created_by will be set when this record is first written. updated will change automatically when changes are made (at least in MySQL) ID is the unique primary key. Created on July 1, 2002

    • Constructor Detail

      • DBObject

        public DBObject(java.sql.Connection Cin,
                java.lang.String tab,
                int IDin)
         throws java.sql.SQLException
        create a DBObject for ID in file tab. Tis is the normal way of getting a single $DBObject for use
        Parameters:
        Cin - A MySQL connection
        tab - The table to look up ID in
        IDin - The ID to get (the row selection unique ID)
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - Usually the network or Database is down

      • DBObject

        public DBObject(java.sql.Connection Cin,
                java.lang.String tab)
         throws java.sql.SQLException
        used for creating DBObject objects which are new rows in the table. when a new one is created, it is read back using the created and created_by fields (unlikely anyone could create more than one record in one table at precisely the right time). It then behaves just like one that was read. Normally, all of the fields in the table are set by calls to the "update????()" routines and then the record made permanent with a call to "updateRecord()".
        Parameters:
        Cin - The Mysql connection
        tab - The table in which to create a new record
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - Usually the network or Database is down

      • DBObject

        public DBObject(java.sql.Connection Cin,
                java.lang.String tab,
                java.lang.String field,
                java.lang.String ID)
         throws java.sql.SQLException
        create a DBObject "where field=id". Note : The query might return more than one row, but this object will only act on the first row returned. There is no checking to see if this is true. It might also create a new row if the "Where field=id" does not match any rows in the table. Use "isNew()" to check this out.
        Parameters:
        Cin - A MySQL connection
        tab - The table to look up ID in
        field - The field name in which to find the ID
        ID - The ID to get (the row selection unique ID)
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - Usually the network or Database is down

    • Method Detail

      • Query

        public static java.sql.ResultSet Query(java.sql.Connection Cin,
                                       java.lang.String tab,
                                       int IDin)
                                throws java.sql.SQLException
        This is just a convenient (or stupid) place to put the a generally QUERY in a table. This returns a result set based on a query of the form "SELECT * FROM tab WHERE ID=IDin;". The returned result set is already positioned to the ID (no need to use rs.next())
        Parameters:
        Cin - Connection to MySQL
        tab - The table for the select statement
        IDin - The ID in the table for this single row
        Returns:
        A result set alread positioned for the row
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - Usually the network or Database is down

      • Query

        public static java.sql.ResultSet Query(java.sql.Connection Cin,
                                       java.lang.String tab,
                                       java.lang.String field,
                                       int IDin)
                                throws java.sql.SQLException
        This is just a convenient (or stupid) place to put the a generally QUERY in a table. This returns a result set based on a query of the form "SELECT * FROM tab WHERE field=IDin;". The returned result set is already positioned to the first row returned. Note : this routine could return more than one row which could be access by ResultSet.next();
        Parameters:
        Cin - Connection to MySQL
        tab - The table for the select statement
        field - The field on which the WHERE clause is to run
        IDin - The ID in the table for this single row
        Returns:
        A result set alread positioned for the row
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - Usually the network or Database is down

      • refreshRecord

        public void refreshRecord()
                   throws java.sql.SQLException
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException

      • updateRecord

        public void updateRecord()
                  throws java.sql.SQLException
        Call this to on DBObject object that is ready for DB update. All of the created, created_by, and updated fields are taken care of here
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - Usually the network or Database is down

      • updateRecord

        public void updateRecord(boolean skipMakeValid)
                  throws java.sql.SQLException
        Call this to on DBObject object that is ready for DB update. All of the created, created_by, and updated fields are taken care of here. If skipMakeValid is true, then the record is not repositioned and its ID is not made known. This is useful if the user is only making new records but does not need them back one made.
        Parameters:
        skipMakeValid - If true, the new record is not repositioned and its ID will not be known
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - Usually the network or Database is down
